description:
Man, how are we so lucky in San Francisco to have so many amazing sushi places? Seriously!! Kingza was very very good last night!  

So someone from yelp who loves sushi as much as I do recommended I check out Kingza. It was not on my radar before but I went to go check it out. Apparently the sushi chef, Tony, had previously worked at a three star Michelin restaurant in New York called Masa and so this restaurant was getting hype. However, when I looked at the yelp reviews, they were very mixed. Fast forward to when I went yesterday, I did not have high expectations since the reviews were not as glowing but the food was amazing!! 

First, they DO NOT skimp on the expensive ingredients. Think multiple slices of wagyu beef, multiple generous portions of Hokkaido uni, great pieces of toro, and huge truffle shavings. My bf was very very impressed. 

Second, they had some super great and unique appetizers. There was this papaya with baked uni custard... just thinking about it again is making me drool. Also they had a great truffle chawamushi!! A lot of times it feels like the appetizers are just some thing before the sushi but here, they were stars in their own right.

Third, the chef's technique is out of this world. A sushi chef (not here) told me that the best chefs in America are from New York but the best fish is in west coast. Well I think we got a great combo here guys!! Each fish was so perfectly cut it glistened with smoothness... you know like how tiger eye looks all polished... like that. Also there was never any stringiness with any of the fish, all of the pieces were selected perfectly. The rice was also the perfect temperature. That cutting technique though.

I can understand people's gripe about this place. It doesn't have the formalism/ceremonial atmosphere most omakase places do. The chef is chatting with people he knows, drinking with the guest, guest are getting drunk and yelling at each other from across the room, etc. But that isn't necessarily a bad thing. It's nice to have a chill place with amazing food. 

The only thing I would note is that it is true the sushi itself is fairly traditional (even though the appetizers are not.) There isn't much by way of marinades, garnishes, etc. This meant that many fishes could seem similar. I didn't have a problem with that but I saw one comment did. My bf, however, did not like that there were two mackerels in the sushi course since he does not like fishy fish. That's just a him thing though LOL
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Really fresh, really tasty - a little overpriced. Been to a few others in the city that I'd say were better value for the quality.

That being said, great service - I described some of the tastes I like and they made me a custom made roll.
author: Alex L.

description:
If you want to sit at the counter, you need to make reservations for it, but my dining partner and I went right when it opened for dinner setting so they were fine with that!  We were the first set and I got all the attention from the chef. 

Chef is really passionate about his sake and sashimi collection!  It's clearly displayed at the counter and nigiri is superbly fresh and delightful!  I opted for their Hitachino Japanese beer because I felt like beer more than sake!  

The signature wins are his appetizers like his Truffle Chawanmushi!  It was appeasing to the taste buds and smell!  Uni amuse bouche was buttery rich and I couldn't get enough!  I would have preferred for truffle toro to be raw instead of seared. It would have tasted better - textured wise!  Chef took time on telling his background and he came to be in SF.  It was a nice story while dining!

All nigiris were savory and treasured with each mouthful!  I was a bit disappointed that the wagyu truffle nigiri didn't get tossed into my omakase!  I was preoccupied besides requesting for this signature nigiri!  Besides that, omakase for the win here!

Service was lovely! 

Lychee sorbet ended the palate - specially flavored and refreshing!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
One of the worst dining experiences I've had for this price. Cost more than $250 for 4 people, could have gotten the same value one of those mall sushi stands.

First off, probably my bad for coming on a Sunday - they get all their fish on Tuesday apparently, and basically dwindles down as the week goes by.

Second, the waiter was terrible, spoke too quietly, and as we would order, he would say they're out of this and that, instead of telling us up front that they're out of a very large quantity of things. Also messed up numerous parts of our order and described menu items inaccurately. Small items were large, large items came out tiny.

Third - the things to not order:
Wakame Salad
Gyoza
Chawanmushi
Black cod
Any tuna item

Honestly, I'd like a refund. Do they have those...?
author: J D.

description:
I would rate the food 5 stars, but we had such an awkward experience here landing this place only 3 stars. 

Came here with 8pm reservations to have omakase at the sushi bar. Usually when we have omakase, we're served each piece one by one for an intimate meal. For some strange reason we were given 5 pieces at a time here. At first I thought this was normal so I brushed it off, but the people next to us were receiving their pieces one by one. Where is the consistency here? Why did we get half the omakase treatment for the SAME PRICE? It really did take away from the experience and not sure why we were excluded from this. We made reservations to specifically sit at the bar to get the full omakase experience. We could have sat at the tables and received the same thing... why tell us specifically on the phone omakase is at the bar @ 5pm and 8pm only??? Weird.

I do have to mention how fresh and delicious the food was. The appetizers were very unique and all extraordinary. Unfortunately, I was confused why we were getting a Grade B experience to truly enjoy the meal. Hard not to look over to our left with eyes of jealously to the people reciting the proper, intimate omakase experience. 

The casual, laid-back environment could have been cool, but now it just seems lazy on their end. For the price we paid, I'd rather go to a more traditional, proper place.
author: Anna M.

description:
Every dish is delicious, and the waiters here will introduce the characteristics of each dish. Papaya with sea urchin makes me amazing. 
Even the simplest dumplings can make me feel the food in my hometown.
author: 品客

description: So delicious! This is our second time eating omakase at Kingza. Chef Tony makes authentic sashimi and changes up his menu so we get to have a different experience every time! He is also super generous with his portion, We always walk away with belly full of delicious sushi  highly recommended!
author: Venus Z.

description:
It's true...I don't impress easily.  Unless I'm drunk

I was pretty impressed at the price they charged for omakase.
I was pretty impressed at the quality of the food, and the spotted prawns that were give at a discount.
I was pretty impressed at the knife skills.

But...please, if you only have two sittings a night, be considerate to those at the second sitting and don't encourage the first people to stay.  

I'll be back, but I'll make sure to be in the first sitting.
author: Ron L.

description:
This is one of the best sushi restaurants in the city, hands down. Quality of the ingredients (e.g. uni from Hokkaido), technique (e.g. stripping the sinews out of the tuna), service and friendly chef set this place apart from many. 

I've been here twice now and each time I've ordered the omakase. And each time was an awesome journey. Make sure to call ahead of time (at least a day) so that they can prepare.

You start off with ~4 appetizers, which are out of this world good. I haven't had these type of appetizers anywhere else until coming here. Different then straight nigiri after the other compared to other high end sushi restaurants. The uni wagyu and chawamushi were my favorite. After that you move on to the nigiri, which is about ~8-10 pieces (I forget the exact number). Each piece is different in terms of flavor and texture, and offer a refreshing and delicious sensation every single time. Tuna was definitely one of the best I've had. Strangely, I also really liked the red snapper. Lastly, as with any high-end sushi establishment I'd expect the uni to be top notch, which it was. The chef learned from Masa in NY and his experience there has carried well over here. Tip: if there's too much wasabi in a piece, you should tell the chef and he'll adjust. 

Above all else, the service was world-class too. It was pouring rain the second time I visited and the chef himself opened up an umbrella and walked me to the car waiting outside. 

Overall, well worth the price. Highly recommend. If you're looking for incredible food and an amazing experience, definitely check this place out because chef Tony and his staff will take care of you.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I'm torn between giving this a 3 or a 4 stars. It's a solid 3.5, but since Yelp doesn't let halves, I'll bump it up to 4! Reservation is pretty easy via Yelp. If you want Omakase you need to book 6pm or 8pm and request for omakase. Parking is pretty hard to find in the area, but we were lucky to have found street parking after going around a few times. One downside is that we were never shown the menu since we asked for omakase, so I have no idea how much I would be paying and what the omakase includes. 

On to the foods! In other omakase restaurant, they always start with the leaner fish first before building up to the much fattier fish. It's the other way around here. We were served fatty tuna twice and wagyu on the first course after appetizers and we ended up with mackerel. All the fishes were good, but I would prefer to have it go from leaner to fattier first. The papaya dish is outstanding! It's very unique and definitely not one we ever tried elsewhere.

We paid $125/person for omakase and we ordered an extra uni which costed us a whooping $13 each. A bit surprising since it's small and compared to how much we were charged for the omakase, I think the uni is overpriced. The omakase itself is worth it for the price, just don't order any additional piece :)
author: Prisilia P.

description:
I read that bringing someone to a sushi restaurant on your first date, boosts your chances of getting a second date by 107%: http://trib.in/2fvaYJr. 

And, this humorous Food & Wine writer suggests going for omakase as a test to see how controlling someone is: http://bit.ly/2nV3b1i. If your date freaks out because there's no menu and you eat whatever the chef brings you, she's probably a "missionary" girl. 

*snorts out tea*

Love it! Unless it's served to you on a pretty platter by a sushi chef, nobody wants a dead fish.

Good sushi is expensive and yes, I think it will probably guarantee you a second date but most likely out of guilt because you spent your entire paycheck on the first date. I think a fancy omakase date should be reserved for when y'all are official but what do I know?

My friend and I've been eyeing Kingza since they opened earlier this year but read mixed reviews on Yelp so we waited it out. Ten months later, we finally decided to take the plunge in this still under the radar sushi restaurant (aka no Biased Bauer review yet). 

No regrets.

Owner/Chef Tony is from NYC and trained with the 3-Michelin starred chef, Masa in NYC (omakase goes for $595 pp there). 

Although they have an a la carte menu, I always spring for the Omakase at a higher end sushi bar to get the chef's best offerings. You receive 6 appetizers, 15-18 nigiri, and dessert for $125 pp. Lots of luxe ingredients like toro, A5 wagyu, truffle, and uni, and we left stuffed so it was a good value. 

Omakase needs to be indicated in your reservations at least 2 days in advance. There's 2 seatings: 6 pm and 8 pm. Parking can be tough in the area so allot extra time so you're not late. 

O  M  A  K  A  S  E  
*Dungeness Crab, cucumber, santa barbara uni: http://bit.ly/2yi0SVK
*Tai Maki, pickle, shiso, avocado, cucumber: http://bit.ly/2BFTzh5
*Kanpachi, truffle, micro greens, fried julienne potato: http://bit.ly/2Be0vBc
*Grilled Uni Custard, baked persimmon: http://bit.ly/2BbPm3h
*A5 Miyazaki w/ shimeji mushrooms, truffle, yuzu, shio kombu: http://bit.ly/2yi8hEF
*Chawanmushi, black truffle, Japanese sesame oil: http://bit.ly/2jCdTbG
*Nigiri (1 of 2): Toro (sinew removed), Seared Otoro, Shima-aji, Engawa, Kinmedai, King Salmon, Tai, Kanpachi, Kurodai: http://bit.ly/2BWhkgO
*Nigiri (2 of 2): Sayori, Kamasu, Aji, Saba, Iwashi, Hokkaido Hotate, Hokkaido Uni, Ume Shisho, Ankimo: http://bit.ly/2iSYKyy
*Housemade Lychee Sorbet: http://bit.ly/2iVwR8X

Highlights:
*The grilled uni custard in a baked persimmon was ridiculously good. The creamy, sweet savoryness with the lightly carmelized crown and salty brininess from the uni was ahhhhmazing. One of the best things I ate this year.
*The dungeness crab w/ uni, the crab was really fresh and sweet, and went well with the creamy briniess of the uni. 
*The kanpachi filled with fried julienned potato was delicious. Loved the texture contrasts. 
*The chawanmushi w/ black truffles was so smooth and silky. 
*Favorite nigiri: toro (sinew removed), kinmedai, king salmon, aji, and saba. 
*The housemade lychee sorbet was refreshing and nicely sweet with fresh pieces of lychee. 

Lowlights:
*The nigiri omakase started with toro. Personally, I think a light to fatty fish progression is better with omakase. 
*Half of the nigiri was just ok. For some of the lighter, white fishes, I think some garnishes could have been added to enhance the flavor. 
*Temperature inconsistencies:
--The first batch of shari (sushi rice) was too warm.
--The uni in the nigiri towards the end of the omakase was super cold and the nori was chewy. Perhaps toasting the nori with a torch would help.
*Not food related but the sushi bar area in front of Chef Tony looked a bit cluttered with the trays, tiny bowls, and knick knacks that weren't used that night. It distracted a bit from the experience. 

We went for the first seating at 6 pm so it was a quiet, enjoyable dinner. Everything was well-paced and took about 75 minutes for the full omakase. 

The staff are very polite and Chef Tony is very friendly. I liked that he checked in to make sure the wasabi levels in the nigiri were ok for us. We were 17 nigri in when he asked if we were "ok" (full). I love a good ankimo so we asked if he had any. He gave us each a piece for no charge. Very kind of him. 

We were ogling the truffle butter and truffle oil in front of us, and Chef Tony insisted that we open the new bottle to give it a whiff. One smell and we were sold. He makes his own line of truffle products and sells it at wholesale to his customers. We each bought a bottle of the Truffle Oil ($15): http://bit.ly/2jCrIqy which will come in handy for pasta dishes at home. 

It was quite quiet for a Saturday evening so it's great for a special occassion date night or splurge meal. Please save the sake bombs and drunken frat boy debauchery for The Marina. 

Despite some of the lowlights, for the reasonable price, the omakase at Kingza is most definitely worth checking out!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Kingza is one of the best omakase in SF. The restaurant itself is pretty casual and offers an alternative menu and omakase ($125) Chef Tony is amazing, fun, talented chef and makes the best omakase. He trained under Masa, the world most expensive sushi restaurant In NYC.
Every dish was flavorful and extremely fresh. This may be one of my favorite omakase so far!!
author: Katie E.

description:
I have to admit, upon doing my preliminary Yelp research, I initially thought Kingza had a slight identity crisis. Unlike some high-end omakase only spots in SF, Kingza's unique because they offer a high-end omakase experience ($125), but also has a more affordable a la carte menu as well (hence their more casual vibe). 

Highlights: 
- A TON of appetizers (some great, some good): the miso cod was the best I've ever had, grilled uni custard in papaya was really unique and interesting, Hokkaido uni and oysters.. mmm

- ~12 ish nigiris. Loved that Chef Tony serves you 9 different kinds of fish and then a few extras of your favorites at the end. We LOVED the barracuda and iwashi, so of course we double up'd on those. 

- Kama toro deserves it's own shout out because that was THEEE best toro I've. Ever. Had. Chef Tony was really excited about this; it was from a 500 pound tuna he broke down earlier that morning. He said it's on YouTube if we wanted to watch, so here it is: https://youtu.be/GoKsko5hN9Q

Not my absolute favorite omakase in the city, but definitely at the top of the pack (4.5 stars!). So glad we decided to make a reservation here despite our initial doubts. 

IMPORTANT! Be sure to call a few days in advance to confirm you're set for omakase since it's by request only!
author: Laverne N.

description:
It's nice to see the increase in quality of Japanese cuisine amongst non-Japanese chefs. More and more chefs are starting to understand the subtle qualities of Japanese food, and that's a great thing. Chef Tony learned his trade under Masa in NYC for a few years, and it shows. 

We got treated to the $125 omakase (thanks bro-in-law!), where everything was superb. The highlights for me were actually the tsumami (appetizers). It's been a few weeks so I forgot what exactly each dish was, but the sliced hotate with uni and ponzu, and a uni truffle chawanmushi/flan was superb.

The nigirizushi is comparable to the best sushi restaurants in the Bay Area, all with high quality fish and good technique on the rice. We had everything from ootoro to aji to hokkaido uni, and all were delicious. Chef Tony does have good technique with forming the nigiri, which I'm sure will get even better with more experience. The only thing I noticed is that the rice tends to be a bit on the sweeter, less-vinegary side, which goes well with some of the fish, whereas some other fish will fare better with a little bit of vinegary acidity.

The best thing, though, is how nice and friendly Chef Tony is. We had a great time chatting with him throughout our meal. This is a business that I really want to see succeed, and we'll definitely be back again!
author: Kazu O.

description:
We had the omakase  and a few things stood out in my mind as being exceptional:

Toro-one if the best I've had, buttery, smooth and paired with warm rice, really hit the spot on a rainy day

A5 wagyu with uni- both of my favorites, the uni from Hokkaido was smooth and delicious

Lychee ice cream- creamy, icy and delicious

The other dishes were a bit disjointed and didn't stand out.  I disliked 2 of the dishes, one was the baked papaya with uni. The taste was just off and the uni tasted sour. The second was the seaweed dish which I saw him scoop onto the fish and was a bit grossed out because it was so stringy and goopy. The abundance of truffle oil was a let down, as I believe the dishes should stand on its own merit. 

Another thing I found odd was starting off with the fattiest part of the fish (toro) to the leanest.  I felt that having such a delicious bite of the toro first and the subsequent fish after was a progressive let down.

I was also disappointed earlier on when I asked the waiter which of the 2 hot sakes he recommended and what the difference was.  He said he didn't know.  Ummm ok.  Can you find out?  I ended up ordering an Asahi beer instead. 

A minor point for me is that even though the chef worked at Masa for 3 years, was that he was Chinese. I avoid sushi places without a Japanese chef (Korean, Thai, Chinese, etc).  The chef was extremely gregarious and nice so it was a nice change switching from talking with my date to the chef.  

Overall, a decent meal but I would rather go to Kusakabe due to the quality of service and fish.  I remember the waiters went above and beyond for us during dinner and that is priceless.
author: Sarah K.

description:
We walked in for some late night sushi on a weekday and accidentally ordered the omakase menu. What a mistake to make!

The food ended up being delicious, and hurting more in the wallet than I had planned. We didn't look up much about this place before going in other than seeing it was sushi and so when the staff asked if we wanted omakase we said why not, not realizing it would set us back $125 per person.

All the food was amazing as all the reviews here mention. My favorites were the wagyu with truffle, the steamed egg with truffle, and the many types of fish were delicious.

There were a few errors in the service that are why this wasn't a 5-star place, though I'd try it again for sure. First, there was some inconsistent seasoning of the fish between me and the other person I was with even though we both expected the same thing and neither of us had indicated to the chef that we had different preferences. My same piece of fish was packed with wasabi and made me cough while my dining partners was much more soy sauce with almost no wasabi.

Second, the service was very very odd. The restaurant was relatively empty aside from us and a group in the back. The staff kept walking in and out of the front door, seemingly to smoke or something else. It wasn't very pleasant as it drew a lot of attention to the staff. Second, the staff kept pouring out our sake for us, which sounds nice but in practice every few minutes someone was struggling to reach between us as we were attempting to have an intimate conversation. I would have preferred to just pour it ourselves and in retrospect I should have spoken up to say that we were comfortable doing so. If the staff has been a bit more attentive to making such a pricey experience, where the food was so good, have service that matched the food, I think it would only improve the experience.
author: Alex H.

description:
Came here with my sister and our friend. Made a reservations and sat at the sushi bar. 

Service (4stars): 
chef Tony is the man! The chef is super entertaining and definitely knows his stuff. 

Food (4stars):
Sushi was very fresh and pieces looked gorgeous. We ordered the omakase very reasonably priced. Hot dishes were spectacular. My favorite was the Uni custard. Nigiri chef made me maybe one of my favorite nigiri of all time, toro topped by a piece of uni! So delicious! 

Highly recommend this spot!
author: Mel S.

description:
This might be the best sushi I've ever had. We started off by ordering the toro daikom which was a truly pleasing dish! It melted in my mouth as I ate each piece. Afterwards we ordered the sushi/sashimi combo which was equally as delicious. It came with a variety of sashimi and a yellowtail scallion roll. Delicious! 

Many more dishes were had that night which continued to please our appetites and taste buds. It's a but pricey but I belive you are getting what you pay for here - quality Japanese food. I highly recommend Kingza to anyone looking for fresh sushi. Perfect for a date night or with friends!
author: Camille G.

description:
My wife and I eat a lot of sushi. From the cheap neighborhood sushi joints to the $300/person omakase restaurants.  Kinza has been on our radar for several weeks, but we wanted to go without our daughter.  Luckily our daughter was invited to a friend's sleep-over, so we immediately made a reservation for later that evening.

We were looking forward to eating here.  Kinza has built up some hype since opening.  We walked in for our reservation and were told we can't sit at the bar.  We have to sit at the tables and cannot order the omakase service.  Apparently, they need to be notified a couple days in advance.  We were told we could come back an hour later for a seating at the bar.  We decided to sit at a table.  Our server was able to get us a couple dishes from the omakase (live uni, caviar dish, and sweet shrimp).

The Uni was great. Simple, straight forward with a little Wasabi. The caviar dish was off. Can't remember the fish, but it was topped with Russian caviar, swimming in vinegar and topped with truffle. It sounds good on paper but there's too much going on. Overkill and lacked balance. The sweet shrimp was great, served with its fried head. I love that one-two combination.

We then ordered a few pieces of nigiri and sashimi. The fish was fresh, good quality, but small. Every piece was cut thin and short.

There were some misfires here and there in terms of service. The staff are well intentioned and work hard to make up for the mistakes.  My wife's exact words, "this place is a bit of a sht show".

Overall the quality is good, but doesn't compare to other omakase restaurants in the Bay Area.  We spent about $200 after drinks, tax and tip. So it's not too expensive, but they are stingy with the cuts.  I'll be back to try the full omakase course, but only after revisiting the better restaurants.  They do need to do a better job communicating their service options. Call the restaurant for reservations if you want omakase.
author: Zoran L.

description:
I went to Kingza with my family on Christmas eve after seeing the great reviews on Yelp.  It's a little neighborhood sushi joint, with a sushi bar and and a handful of tables of 2 and 4.  We sat in a table of 4 in the window and the table was tight, especially as the sushi started arriving.  We found the service to be somewhat lacking as there were only two servers covering the restaurant, but they were very nice when they did find their way to our table.  

The menu was somewhat disappointing in terms of the different types of fish.  I thought the menu was somewhat limited compared to many other sushi places.  We ordered the salmon platter, the tuna platter, and several rolls.  The sushi was very good.  The tuna/salmon platters include nirgiri, sashimi, and a roll, and the sushi was very tasty.  The rolls were also tasty.  

Depsite the tight quarters and limited menu, I was a fan and would come back again.
author: Benjamin v.

description: Chefs been chill. Vibes been good. I think the core of omakase is the communication about the foods with the chef (I.e. Telling what fish it is and why it's selected). Chef Tony's been good about that. Better try it before it raises its price as it's clearly one of the places that attempt to get attentions by setting the lower prices with a good quality... (I still remember yoshizumi used to be 90 per person LOL)
author: Tom H.

description: Sushi was fair...not great but not bad. In the city there are so many choices for great sushi that I will not be back. The ambiance is nice, better than some other sushi spots but I go to sushi restaurants for the sushi not really the ambiance. Also I think it's Chinese owned and not Japanese owned and I find Japanese owned sushi spots to be more authentic and they seem to care about quality more so than others. Just my opinion...
author: Marsha L.

description: Kinda pricey but its acceptable. They was very busy with little servers, so sometimes it's hard to get something. Food is good&fresh. The beer collection is pretty various, 山椒 is worth a try if you like Japanese beer.
author: Tina Z.

description:
If I could, I would come here for omakase everyday! But of course, I cannot afford that so this will be for special occasions only. 

I made reservations for 2 on yelp with a note for omakase and called to confirm. When we arrived, we were seated at the bar promptly and given the drink menu and glasses of water. We shared a bottle of sake though out our meal but they never failed to keep our water glasses filled. They were very attentive. They were efficient with removing the dishes and wiping down our wooden blocks used for sashimi. 

For our omakase, we had 6 appetizers, 13 nigiri + 1 extra toro + 1 choose one to have again + 1 semihandroll, and of course a dessert. The phrase "come hungry leave happy" perfectly described our night. We had a lot of sashimi from Japan, truffles, and I even tried uni for the first time and man did I fall in love. Each fish was freshly made for us and they were fresh and addicting! You can customize you nigiri. Kinda. Let the chef know if you want more/less wasabi, soy sauce, and even rice! The typical amount is not bad, and considering I never eat my sushi with wasabi, I thought it was the perfect amount. There were a few pieces that had a little too much and went up our noses. I could have asked for less wasabi but I wasn't at the point of no return from too much wasabi so it was on me, but we had a great laugh about it. We were also able to try the wagyu beef I seen photos with and OMG. You seriously need to try it, the meat just melts in your mouth, I usually don't eat/care too much about meat, but give me a plate of this and I'm not sharing. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. 

Lastly, the dessert. It was a lychee sorbet. I really wish I could buy a tub of this but it will forever be in my memories. There was a strong lychee flavor with lychee bits but most importantly it was a sorbet that wasn't too sour. 

If you haven't been convinced by this review to try their omakase, I don't know what you eat but its obviously not the amazing food I had.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
This is better than most omakases in the area.  

ONE reason: rice temperature, it's perfectly warm throughout the meal.  

Yes the fish is awesome and the chef, Tony apprenticed under Masa in NYC.  I thought this was close and at a third of the price.  Um, score!!!

Come before people catch on or before Michelin ruins it.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I was excited to try this place out and it fell flat in every way.

I made reservations and asked to sit at the bar but when I asked about the Omakase, the waiter said we had to have requested it beforehand - HOW WAS I SUPPOSED TO KNOW THAT? This is not clear AT ALL. This was the only reason we came here and instead had to order a la carte.

That aside, here is the breakdown of our subpar experience:

Service: Extremely slow. We got our first dish 40 mins in and the next one 40 mins after that. Unbelievable. We ended up having more sake than we needed to since we had already committed to eating here. Also, our waiter was not very friendly and every time we got a dish served no one bothered to tell us what it was. Most other sushi places have better service than this. Beyond "apologizing" for the ridiculous wait, nothing else was offered. 

Food: We ordered a variety of dishes and nothing stood out. We had the wagyu beef, yellowtail jalapeño, live uni & sushi special. Wagyu beef was $35 and not worth it AT ALL. As was everything else. Totally disappointing. Fish was OK, not terrible but not great (again, i'm comparing to the price)

Seeing the bill at the end of the meal was the biggest shock because we did not see the value at all. I had the intention of coming back for the omakase but after this experience, won't be coming back at all.

NOT GOOD, So many better sushi places in the city at a better value.
author: Laura D.

description:
Service was really disappointing! We were a party of six sitting in the back room, and we were forgotten a lot. There were two uncoordinating servers so one would take orders and then the second one would stop by to see if we were ok so we ended up having to say we were waiting. Some if the dishes came out, but not the appetizers. Those came after a reminder or two at the end if the meal. Someone's side never came out and we ended up canceling it. Finally, there was a fish we didn't immediately recognize and when we asked the server, she had to go ask the chef what it was!!
Once the bill was brought, after what seemed a normal amount of time, we had to chase them down. 

So that was service. I can accept mediocre service if there's amazing food involved, but it wasn't.

The sashimi was served over a huge bowl of ice cubes so the fish didn't shine through at the colder temperature. The sushi was smallish and the prices were high. We all agreed that the fish was fresh, but you can get quality fish in many places. People enjoyed the egg and truffle appetizer. The best part of the meal was the hamachi kama. 

The hamachi Kama was perfect! Finally, something great about this place.

I feel bad for the out of town friends who chose this particular spot because of the chef's training.
author: Susan B.

description:
Kingza gets a solid 4.5 stars from me!

The restaurant itself is pretty casual and offers an alternative (and more affordable) à la carte menu in addition to omakase. If you opt for the omakase (~$125), you'll sit at the sushi bar and be served by chef Tony, who is the owner.

To start, Laverne N. and I were presented with a flurry of appetizers -- abalone, beef skewers, uni custard in papaya (so unique!), AMAZING miso cod, etc. Then came the nigiri -- my favs were the kama toro, barracuda, and a5 wagyu with shaved black truffle (what's new, lol). The uni handroll was also delicious!

I'd say the best part of the experience was chef Tony's enthusiasm for the food and willingness to chat with his patrons about each and every dish; he even showed us the certificate of the cow from which our wagyu came from. :x Definitely the most engaged I've ever been during an omakase.

Highly recommended, especially if you prefer not to dress up for dinner!
author: Jennifer K.

description: I absolutely love love this place and will definitely be back! Chef Tony is awesome. Told him I liked uni and toro. He made several dishes with uni with was pretty damn amazing. He made this delicious uni custard where you can not get anywhere else. Tony also makes his own truffle sauce. How cool is that?!?! Fish was really fresh and the wagyu was melt in your mouth. Definitely worth your money to eat here! Everything from the food to service was A plus plus! Such a great experience and would definitely come back!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
4.5 stars
Delicious, authentic Japanese cuisine, but for a steep price. Expect quality not quantity. 

My bf wanted to try it out because he read that the sushi chef used to work under a 3 Michelin star restaurant in New York.

We tried:
-yellow tail topped with jalapeño ($16): I liked this even though I usually don't like jalapeños on anything.

-soft shell crab ($12)
-sashimi tastings (1 for each of us)
-scallop and unagi pieces

They don't have much of a dessert selection except for ice cream which I didn't try. 

Overall, Kingza is a great new addition to the neighborhood. Delicious but pricey. Try it now while there aren't lines out the door!
author: Corinna T.

description:
Came for the Omakase and unfortunately I was underwhelmed--price/value/expertise/service. compared to other similarly priced Omakase options in the city, this restaurant doesn't add up. 

The team doesn't seem to be an experienced one. Their fish cuts are inconsistent, their service is as well, and their hot food is very hit or miss. 

For the price, this place is not worthwhile. Its too bad because they do have high quality fish, but they aren't doing the fish justice. 

Also, I felt they overused truffles on too many dishes as a means of seeming "fancy." The fish really doesn't need it.
author: Shanee B.

description:
LOOOOOOOVVVVVVED THIS PLACE!!!!!!!! 

We made reservations for a Tuesday night. After reading the reviews for Kingza, I knew that my boyfriend and I had to come and we HAD to order omakase ($125 per person). We had reservations for 6:30pm and were promptly seated. In order to order omakase, you need to specify that you will be ordering omakase when you make your reservation. 

Everything we had was excellent. Everything was seasoned right, and both the fishand meat melted in your mouth. You could tell that everything was so fresh. And because we sat at the sushi bar, we were able to interact with Chef Tony all night long. He is an extremely nice guy and very talented. This chef made me an uni believer. When I walked into this place, I knew I didn't like uni. However, the chef made me try both the Santa Barbara uni and the Maine uni. He was right, I did like uni!! And foie gras nigiri......enough said. 

I've been to other omakase places in the city, like Kusakabe, and this is definitely my favorite. 

And yes, they don't have a website yet. They are currently developing it and will hopefully be up and running soon. 

I cannot wait to come back! You will not regret coming here for omakase.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Outstanding omakase, one of the best in the city, especially for the price ($125).  We received four appetizers, creative and exquisitely presented, and then about 10 pieces of nigiri sushi of the highest quality.  Chef Tony was friendly and invited feedback (we had only positive feedback for him).

The service was friendly but a bit slow, I think because there are not set seating times for the omakase.  We were lucky to sit right in front of Chef Tony.  If you sit further down the sushi bar, it could get awkward receiving the sushi as the chef has to hand it to you over the counter and you can't talk to him as easily.  We would definitely return.
author: Neill T.

description: The food was decent, the service was SHITza. They didn't have half of the menu items, they charged me for food that was never brought out, servers are nice but inexperienced and kept asking how everything was while i was reminding them to bring me the food I ordered an hour before.
author: Marco P.

description: lovely Omakase experience for two - Highly recommend sitting at the chefs table, great fish and array of flavors. Will return!
author: Deanna C.

description:
By far the worst omakase restaurant I'd been to. It was my first time trying kingza, and I was super excited! I kept hearing people talk about it saying how good it was, how the over truffle your nigiri. Like come on, how can you really say no to truffle?!? Once me and my bf got there, we got seated very quickly before we made rsvp. The restaurant wasn't a place where it's dedicated to just omakase, they have regular menu as well. There were 8 of us total sitting at the bar area that was having omakase. So the list of bad things start...

I tried ordering a bottle of nanbubijin sake. But the waitress came back and said they didn't have it, and was recommending us another kind. Assuming she knew what she was doing and talking, we went along with it. But it turns out it was umeshu (plum liqueur, it was not even sake. The waitress also said it's a dry sake when it's not. The couple next to us also ordered a bottle of nigori sake (unfiltered sake) but the waitress didn't even shake it before serving it to me. Lack of experience! I couldn't help but lean over and tell the couple that they have to shake before serve. 

The chef put so much thoughts into the appetizers, which was amazing btw. But when it got to the nigiri, omg it was not what I was expecting! They all taste the same because they don't even bother garnishing the fish beside the soy sauce that they brush on top, for every single piece, same! Like at least some green onions, lemon zest or truffle or something!  For the price, i felt like the quality of the fish was like just mediocre. If they don't mention the type of fish to me, you probably couldn't tell much difference from the kind you can get from the Japanese market. And each piece took really long to come out because the chef had to make other customer's order (the people that wasn't part of the omakase party). AND we had to put our plate out to reach for our nigiri, I feel like since I'm paying for the piece $125pp I should be served and not reach out for my own food just cause the chef couldn't reach us. I felt like I was at a cafeteria getting food. 

Let's just say me and my boyfriend couldn't wait for the experience to be over so we can just pay and leave.
author: Carol Y.

description: I just wanted to update my review. I would be giving zero stars if I could. Since I previously reviewed, the manager of Kingza, Howard, reached out to me on Yelp promising a free omakase for their mistake around Valentine's Day. I responded, but he never got back to me. Disappointing.
author: Ben S.

description: Great place for fresh sushi and great service. The servers came back a lot to make sure everything was ok. The live uni was fresh and orange clam was viciously tasteful. One of the best spots for an intimate delicious dinner. I made a note that it was a birthday and they brought out a complimentary lychee ice cream. Would definitely come back. Prices are a bit pricey but worth it for the standard help in SF.
author: Drew L.

description: Omakase with amazing chef Tony. One of my best foodie experience EVER. The restaurant has a very nice ambiance, and decent decor. The appetizers are unique, the ingredients are picked with care to the balance on taste. I first thought the truffle and truffle oils would be too overpowering, but the chef pace out the sushi really well. Would recommend all to try out this place.
author: Janet H.

description: Nicely designed restaurant. Ran out of uni appetizer when we went. Ordered the sashimi and sushi specials plus some shishito peppers and hamachi kama. The cooked food was pretty good. Fish in both sashimi and sushi specials were the same (tuna, salmon, yellowtail, mackerel, butterfish i think) with cuts of fish being on smaller side. The main issue and hence the 3-star rating was that the fish didn't taste particularly high quality or fresh. Price is very reasonable for SF, service is friendly, but was hoping for better sushi.
author: Sherman L.

description:
Pretty disappointed with Kingza to be honest. 

Appetizer
The presentation of each appetizer was very beautiful. It made it seem like it was so full of flavors and made me couldnt wait to devour it. However, when I tasted it, it was just okay. Nothing surprised me. The appetizer also came out VERY SLOW. i was really hungry and the service disappointed me. 

Nigiri
Chef Tony did great preparing my dinner, however the other chef needs more training. Some of the fish were cut by the other chef and one of my nigiri's fish was too thin and does not cover the whole rice. Whats worst was that one of the nigiri still have the fish bone! I have to spit it out because its not the edible thin bone. The moment I saw the bone from the fish ruined my mood and I just cant wait to go home. The amount of wasabi was not consistent too. i had to ask 3 times to make it less. So far, this is my worst omakase experience after paying almost $200 

Dessert
I was served a homemade sorbet. I think it was lychee and it tasted really good. It was the highlight of my omakase dinner!

Although, i need to say that Chef Tony is a great and kind guy. He apologized to the customers when his friends was dining there that night and made a lot of noise because they were drunk. He also thanked us all and always tell us if we want any adjusments to the sushi (sauce, rice temp, wasabi, etc).
author: Kimberly S.

description: The restaurant called us right before our reservations and was able to upgrade us to a counter seat. The Omakase was extremely tasty - we walked out very satisfied.  We paired the food with an expensive bottle of sake.  Overall a very nice experience; service was attentive and helpful.
author: Frank G.

description: This is the most stunning Japanese restaurants the bay. All the chiefs and waiters are nice. Foods are fantastic. It is the best place to bring your love one to.
author: Jacky L.

description:
Oh my goodness, Kingza was freaking amazing. Chef Tony is a fun, boastful, yet extremely talented chef with an incredibly jovial personality. Get him talking, and he'll be your best friend for the night. Ask him about his truffles! Tony kept serving nigiri upon nigiri to us, going far beyond the set menu for fun. There's no ala-cart menu. Tony serves what Tony wants to. For our dinner, he starts off with TWO pieces of toro! We ended up with 15+ pieces of nigiri along with a 6 very hearty appetizers. It wasn't just quantity though, the quality of the fish, rice, and knife work was absolutely top knotch.

Tony trained under at the world renowned restaurant Masa in NYC under the notoriously strict Masa Takayama. Tony's goal was to replicate the spirit of Masa-san's menu at a much more accessible price; Masa is the world's most expensive sushi restaurant after all. I'll have to say, Tony sure made an incredible impression and deserves a job well done. Definitely a place to come back to.
author: Ye L.

description: Dining at the restaurant here is a fantastic unforgettable experience, the Chef Tony is a legend. Me and my friend enjoyed his sushi very much.
author: Terry C.

description:
After our first time here, we have made 3 more reservations for next week and next, next week. Our new favorite omakase place!

We made reservations and specified we wanted the omakase.

The staff and Chef Tony were really wonderful, and the food was very good! Although our omakase dinner was a slower pace than usual, we didn't mind watching Chef Tony put together dishes--it's easy to see that he's passionate about his craft. We recently visited another omakase place in SF and paid more, but the food here was more enjoyable.

Every dish was flavorful and fresh. Our favorites were: ebi appetizer, fresh Santa Barbara uni, blue fin tuna, and hamachi kama nigiri. At the end, chef Tony asked us which we liked best, and he prepared a second serving for us. At the end, we were served lychee ice cream. We ordered a large bottle of sake (720ml) with our dinner, and during dinner, chef Tony let us try his favorite plum wine and sake. 

A thoroughly wonderful experience. Chef Tony apologized more than once for the wait time, and was very amicable and accommodating. 

Our total for 2 omakase, a large bottle of sake and tip came out to a little over $400--this is reasonable for omakase and probably the least we've paid.
author: Vy L.

description:
The original intention was to come for a sushi bar omakase since the chef trained at Masa, but we ended up coming as a larger group, so we just did a table.  

We started with some shared appetizers:
- Wagyu tataki: pretty solid 
- Oysters with ponzu: good flavor on the ponzu sauce
- Live uni sashimi: impressive presentation with the sea urchin opened up and the pieces of uni on top. It was super fresh and creamy, better than most uni I've had
- Miso cod: we were all surprised at how tiny the piece was for $15; flavor wise, it was less sweet than expected, which is fine, but the portion was just really small 

We then each got a sushi tasting (7 nigiri + maki) for $30, which is a super reasonable price.
- Maki: salmon roll and a yellowtail and scallion maki 
- Nigiri: 7 pieces, including hirami, wild king salmon, sea bream, shima aji, tuna

The sushi rice texture was good, but I wished it had more flavor.  I assume that for the omakase, the nigiri are individually seasoned, but ours came with just wasabi, so you had to dip the pieces in soy sauce.  All of the fish was fresh.

I wasn't quite sure what to expect - I thought it may be similar to the other higher end omakase places, but it's a more relaxed vibe.  Still, the omakase at the sushi bar is not cheap. Based on the photos on yelp, it does seem like they do more seasoning with the nigiri pieces in the omakase compared to with the sushi tasting. 

I'm usually not an uni fan, but I would say the highlight of the meal was the uni.

It wasn't hard to get a reservation, and the Mission is easy to get to for those of us who live on the peninsula.  In the end, without alcohol, the total was around $60/person including tax/tip/SF mandate.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
This was probably one of the best meals that I have ever had in my life - and I have lived in four different countries and traveled to 27 other ones.  My friend and I were here for his birthday on a Thursday evening.  Kingza has only been open for a few weeks (maybe about a month?) and we were able to secure a reservation for two easily.  We decided to go with Chef's Selection of several courses (Omakase?) for the evening although definitely make sure to specify that in your reservation as sometimes they may not be able to satisfy your request last minute.

The wait staff all greeted us with a smile and gave us helpful suggestions when it came to sake selection.  We went with a reasonably priced bottle that was just the right amount of sweetness and I appreciated how our waiter politely steered us away from a Nigori that we might have regretted :)

The obvious highlight of the experience was the several course selection of sushi.  We started off with an oyster dish with salmon roe, which was amazing and had such beautiful presentation.  From there, we went through a journey of several kinds of fishes, ranging from beautiful cuts of tuna and salmon to barracuda.  I got to try several different kinds of fish that I had never had before (although the names escape me right now) along with foie gras sushi, which was AMAZING!!  Another highlight of the meal was Waygu beef with Matsutake mushroom.  

I seriously felt like this was not only a food experience, but an educational experience for me as well.  I felt like I was experiencing the real taste of fish for the first time and loved watching Tony preparing our dishes.  It is very clear that Tony has a love for what he does and he shows it in his craft.  The meal was worth every penny and I will definitely be back in the future and telling all of my friends!!
author: Zarina Z.

description:
Recently came to Kingza to experience the omakase and we were blown away! The ambiance of the restaurant was welcoming. It was mesmerizing to watch Chef Tony prepare each item for the omakase. He informed us about each type of fish/ingredient as he served it.  Wait staff were attentive. 

Favorites: uni, wagyu nigiri, sea bream, toro and king salmon. 

Would definitely return! Make sure to make reservations if you intend to enjoy the omakase: ) The sushi bar was fully occupied throughout our visit.
author: L H.

description:
Reminds me of Hinata. The owners are good friends. This is Chinese owned, but Chef Tony does know his stuff. If you love UNI and Truffles this is the place to be. $120 for Omakase. You get a lot of food. At least 5 appetizers before the nigiri comes out. On their site it says you can get up to 15 to 18 pieces of nigiri. We tapped out at 13. I don't like Uni, but their Uni flan was super good. All the appetizers were the best, especially the truffle wagu beef. The fishes were fresh. Some stood out more then others. Loved my toro handroll. Chef Tony just keeps on giving and doesn't charge more. 

Place is spacious. Make reservations for the bar. The rest of the service was a bit spotty.
author: Karen H.

description:
dayyyyyym y'all i walked in... barry white onhit. ate ate ate then barry white again at the end. as if that wasn't enough, guess what happened in the bathroom? dionne warwick bz. w a fing disco waterfall tree lol.

* i recommend calling ahead to check if what you want is in stock; out of uni & lobster when i went :( *

food largely blandish but nice service. patient as i asked the specials (secretmenu on server's cliffnotes) like 5x.

(^_^) Soft Shell Crab Karaage $12 (http://bit.ly/2m6sNp3)
i piled a ton of ginger & wasabi

(^_^) Botan Ebi Sashimi $15 (http://bit.ly/2m6kIAE)
fun; can eat the whole shell head

(-_^) Asparagus Tempura $8 (http://bit.ly/2lJg74L)
so i can pretend to be healthy

(-_^) Tako Wasabi Offmenu $7 (http://bit.ly/2mCD1ie)
wasabi could have sharper sting

(-_^) Foie Gras Sushi Offmenu $7 (http://bit.ly/2moeXPS)
main flavor was salt

(-_^) Homemade Dumpling $10 (http://bit.ly/2mXaVdB)
pork, chives, shrimp. use the sauce

(-_^) Ankimo Appetizer $10 (http://bit.ly/2momwG3)
okish

told me they've been open 5 days so far and plan to add more to the menu like rolls, omakase, unique fish, etc. i said just add the lobster & uni and i'm set. maybe iced tea.

some staff spoke chinese, plus chinese "housewarming" plants all over...? bienvenidos amigos!
author: Dan B.

description:
Restaurant has a nice ambiance, staff is lovely, fish is incredibly fresh and Chef Tony is awesome.

Chef Tony elegantly creates, delivers, and explains. He shows genuine care for his customers preferences; consistently making sure the pace and taste were all up to our satisfaction. He also made great conversation of his experience and passion for what he does. Definitely the most engaging omakase chef I've encountered. 
Every single dish was delectable and makes you go "mmmmm". The uni in particular was extremely fresh and sweet. Kumamoto oysters? Yes yes yes!!! Oh and can we please have a moment of HOORAY for the truffle that Chef Tony incorporates?!?

Omakase is about trusting your chef and I would trust my meal to Chef Tony again for sure. This may be one of my favorite omakase so far!
author: Susan C.

description:
I came here with a reservation for 4 at the bar for a girlfriend's birthday. The service was really welcoming and food was exquisite! I feel like this place is a hit or miss since I saw bad reviews, but because of that, I came here with low expectations - however, everything exceeded expectations! 

For the first 5 dishes, they were appetizers before the nigiri - very different from most omakase spots as appetizers would come in between every few nigiri pieces. I was most impressed with the first 5 appetizers being top omakase dishes like uni, truffle-flavored almost everything and wagyu! The nigiri pieces were all super soft and rich in flavor - they keep the fresh fish at perfect room temperature or something for it to melt in my mouth dish after dish. Also, the chefs here are super generous with truffle - mMmMm!

- Kanisu (fresh dungeness crab salad with summer cucumber vinaigrette topped with fresh uni): I enjoyed the strong vinaigarette and citrus taste to the crab salad and the fresh uni on top was the cherry on top. For the first dish of the meal, I am very impressed uni was a starter!
- 2 Oysters (house ponzu, scallions and wasabi caviar): oysters were tasty and fresh with the rich flavors from the house ponzu and a kick with the wasabi caviar - yum!
- Baby Abalone: Didn't see this on the menu, but wow am I once again impressed with an abalone dish (delicacy). The abalone doesn't have a fishy taste - so they cooked it perfectly! Chewiness was perfect as it wasn't hard to chew off and had a slight marinated taste that got me wanting more!
- Sweet shrimp ceviche (sweet shrimp, microgreens, watermelon topped with caviar): this dish was also tasty with the texture of watermelon underneath. Edible flowers and veggies as the microgreens - interesting, but super yum!
- Grilled Uni custard with papaya: This has got to be one of my favorite appetizers - grilled uni custard is so delicious when placed on top of papaya pieces topped with truffle! Grilled uni was so rich and definitely didn't have the fishy taste they usually have when raw. The truffle helped make it even more rich. I would totally order this again.
-Wagyu carpaccio (seared A5 Miyazaki wagyu beef topped with summer truffle): This is also one of my favorite appetizers! We got 3 wagyu pieces with a lot of summer truffle on top - super generous and melt-in-your-mouth goodness! I ate this dish slowly because I wanted to savor every bit of it.
- Truffle Chawanmushi (Japanese steamed egg with truffle): Also made it to my top 3 appetizers of the evening. Usually, the steamed egg is pretty normal and nothing outstanding, but I must say, this one had truffle in every taste! Super amazing and would definitely reorder too!

We get a total of 12 nigiri pieces and the first two nigiri pieces were chu toro and o-toro... whaaaat?! Usually, chefs save the best for last - but we got to enjoy yummy toro first! Another nigiri favorite was the butterfish topped with summer truffle, scallop, and uni handroll. Since it was my girlfriend's birthday, they gave her an extra uni handroll - how nice! We all also got a shot of tasty fruity sake to cheers with the chef too - wow. The service is amazing and food was exceptional. We all ended our meal with a lychee sorbet that had actual lychee jelly pieces inside - mMm! The total was $217 per person (3 people) including the birthday girl's portion. Worth the price with the amazing service and food :) Will be back soon Chef Tony!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Bravo!
One of the best Japanese restaurants in San Francisco ! I was so lucky to try out this new restaurant. My friends and I had some of the best meals of our lives here! It's simply AMAZING!
Recommendation...EVERYTHING ! First of all, this place is Omakase, which means the chef decides what he is going to give you. The chef worked in Masa before. His master is Masa. And other chef I didn't have the opportunity to interact with.
The ambiance was very clean n retro. I really love this place. 
Spend the money... you will know it was worth it!
Will definitely be going back!
author: Yuye Z.

description:
Decor of restaurant was nice. Food was between decent to average. Uni custard served in an uni shell - custard wasn't bad...presentation was nice...cool but I did not taste any uni at all!? Zero. Wagyu + truffle was decent but portion was tiny. Service was heavy on the pretty bad side. Waiter definitely needed some additional training or better...a career outside of the restaurant business. The menu looked good...3 pages good...too bad half of it was not available! The waiter stood there rejecting our orders one after the other. Out of 12-15 or so items we tried to order...we were able to get about 6. And to top it off, pricing on receipt did not match price listed on menu (I had to point this out so that they could correct it...a couple of items were marked up $1 more). I was really excited to check this place out but a big disappointment it was. I did go on a Sunday so maybe it was a bad day yo go? But I personally think every day/experience for a highet end place should be a good oneone.

Meh. Not recommended. If you do go...Tuesday, Thursday is when they order their fish so they should have the supply
author: .I I.

description: The materials in the restaurant are delicious and fresh. My like the beef, uni and the toro. The chef is very nice and I would definitely come back.
author: Raina L.

description:
Very excellent service, when we had the omakase here for early Mother's Day, chef Tony insisted on precision and quality throughout the whole entire meal. He was willing to engage in conversation and the flavors played together magically. Our favorite has to be the second course of the omakase. The salmon roe with fire squid tasted absolutely amazing. 
All in all one of the best nights we've had in San Francisco.
author: Henry W.

description: Their uni was the best. I liked the overall experience there. Not the best sushi place in the world but it was a decent one, and I enjoyed the dinner.
author: Irene C.

description:
The best sushi in SF. Chef Tony is amazing and makes the best omakase!

Each dish after the other only gets better. Just the appetizers alone, with its phenomenal use of ingredients like truffle, make this meal worth it. 

The tuna is special, like no other. They strip out the sinus by hand themselves in the tuna so all your left with is the mouth pleasing fatty meat. 

I highly recommend everyone come here if you're looking for an undercover sushi spot. Better than any high end sushi spot with less of wait.
author: Anna K.

description:
4 stars for food. 3 stars for service.  Party of 2 made reservations for 8pm. Kingza felt like a casual friendly neighborhood sushi bar with a high end price tag.

Cons
- Like the other yelpers, I agree that service needs alot of work. Waitstaff not experienced. We got here on time and the waitress/hostess apologized for the delay due to patrons still eating which was totally fine but another couple got seated before us and my friend mentioned that and she did not know what to do but the other couple realize it and let us sit first. The waitress also asked us some things that were kind of offensive like when we asked for recs on sake, she asked us what our price range was. I don't understand why that would matter if we wanted the best sakes they had to offer. The better question would be what taste or type of sake I prefer.  Also, she never checked on us and the owner had to pour us water instead. I overheard him say to her to check on us more. She came back and ask if we wanted to move seats instead which was strange.

- Prepare to wait. Food comes out slow.. don't go there hungry
- Unfiltered sake selection was not high end or hard to find in your local market. Need a better selection.


Pros
- This could have been an one off event but hands down, the omakase bar patrons really made the night. Everyone was friendly and Tony, the owner went around to chat with everyone. One lady ordered a $600 bottle of sake and shared it with the table of 12.  It was a rowdy and happy Friday group.
- The food! uni was a topping on 3 of the plates and there was caviar and truffles involved on some of the nigiri sushis.  
-Unique sashimi pieces and combination of ingredients was refreshing.

Tony did some upselling where he showed the patron some fresh live shrimp and went around to ask who wants one. If you say yes, it's an extra $10. Not sure if this is a pro or a con lol
author: Kelly C.

description: Really good sushi place in the mission. Great omakase that included quite a few appetizer and nigiri courses. A liberal amount of truffle was incorporated into quite a few courses which was really nice. The fish and uni were all really fresh. Finally, the service was fantastic. Our chef Tony made the experience really enjoyable and memorable.
author: George Z.

description:
My husband and I just returned from a 12 day food trip from Japan, and dined at some amazing sushi restaurants including Jiro. We walked in expecting to be disappointed since it was the first sushi we were having since Japan. However, we were not disappointed. The sushi nigiri was very impressive. A few of stand out pieces was his deep sea snapper, Ika, orange clam and amaebi. Everything else was solid as well. 
We are looking forward to returning as Chef Tony is a chef who will be improving. The restaurant is still new and fine tuning its menu, but we are excited to see what's in store for us our next visit. 
Definitely make a reservation and get the omakase. totally worth it.
author: Linda L.

description:
DONT GO HERE unless you are here for omakase.  Bar sitting seems very nice. 4 chef served 12 customers and only two server served the entire restaurant.

Food on menu was pricy, not worth the money.

Service was Horrible. The waiter and waitress forget your order. I had to go up to the front and  remind them to bring the check, bring the sake glass and plate to our table.

not even worth to deserve a start. btw.. please do train your waiters.

Thanks!
author: Helen C.

description: After Kusukabe, Kingza is easily the best omakase in San Francisco. The price is also very reasonable as Kingza is still a new restaurant. Not to be missed! The staff was very friendly and engaging, they were also flexible and let a couple of us start the omakase despite the fact that the whole party had not arrived.
author: Neha S.

description: Outstanding omakase high quality fish. I highly recommend this place. Especially if you are into truffle it's a must. Chef Tony is one amazing and he knows his stuff. Looking forward to come back to Kingza.
author: Calvin N.

description:
I used to go there when it was Kiji. Decor was the k and sushi was above average and menu was interesting. 

Now Kingza, which the waitress tells me has been open for 4 months, is very different. 

I absolutely love the sushi bar - a very smooth solid piece of timber and well maintained with no stains. But that about all I can brag to you about. 

The sushi menu was lacking. Very plain. And what they did offer was WAY overpriced. For example - sashimi is $5 per slice, and it is sliced razor thin - I mean I ordered four pieces of hamachi and it was, not exaggerating here, it was the thickness of a quarter and about two inches long. Other places if get more meat in one piece than I got in four, so that was a wasted $20. So thin you can't even taste it. 

The salmon sampler - 4 sashimi, 4 nigiri, and 6 maki, was $26. The sashimi was a little thicker than the hamachi, the nigiri about average, and the maki was so painstakingly assembled with the thinnest slice of salmon he could muster from the blade. 

For $4 a bowl of miso soup was so watered down and bland it tasted like water with a piece of seaweed floating in it. 

I should have known, as Kiji it was always packed. This time there was only one table occupied by obvious tourists. 

Overall $95 for two and we went home to eat ramen.
author: Bill B.

description:
Kingza has a lot of promise, but fell a little flat. On the positive side, it feels like an authentic Japanese sushi bar and I really enjoyed the Sake I was recommended. For dinner I selected the sushi tasting menu which came with 7 pieces of nigiri and 6 pieces of maki. The nigiri was edible and filling but missed the taste I would expect given the price. I felt the quality of fish was lackluster and the quantity of rice too much. The maki was not memorable at all.  For a side I had a bowl of miso which was quite amazing, but didn't make up for the sushi. 

Overall I don't think I would go back. There are so many amazing sushi restaurants only blocks away which offer better quality for the same or cheaper price.
author: Carl S.

description: I have to say this is very special and creative sushi spot. Chef Tony is creative and fun, I try lot special sushi that I never tried other sushi restaurant,  I don't know much about sushi but I have to say I love everything he chooses for me to tasted. My mom  don't like raw food and chef make all special cooked food for her. And I love raw food especially oyster with his special sauce that tastes awesome!! Will be back soon
author: Queenie C.

description: Out of all the sushi restaurant I've been to, Kingza is one best tasting places I've been to. Their fish is extremely fresh and satisfying. Chef Tony, the head chef, was very knowledgeable and very kind. He knew what he was doing and was willing to explain everything he put out. The service was great and the food was amazing with a reasonable price.
author: Lina T.

description:
Five-star! The meals here that's pretty unforgettable.
Very comfortable place, don't let the small place fool you, it's so awesome!
Absolutely fantastic food. Good Fish, fresh, well cut and tasty! Great sushi and service for sure.
You must sit the bar if u come here, it's a true experience for any lover of Japanese cuisine. 
I can't believe I'm having prix fixe menu by the chef which is from NY Masa. 
I will be back for sure, come and try, u will love it
author: Ice Z.

description: Took my girlfriend here for her birthday celebration and this was the longest 4 hour dinner we ever had on a Friday night, but it was a great experience overall. Almost every dish consist of summer truffles, if your a fan of truffles you would love their omakase menu by requests. The fish portions are smaller than other places, but still really delicious. I definitely love their papaya baked with uni and topped off with summer truffles which stood out to me. Another starter which stood out was their truffle tiramisu, which we thought it was some sort of soup until we digged into it! Haha  Last but not least, their Japanese A5 Wagyu beef with summer truffles just melts right into your mouth. I would definitely come back for their omakase menu!
author: Pam Ela Y.

description:
We had high expectations from this place ... unfortunately, it didn't deliver. 

Came here during a week night with some friends. We had heard good things about the chef and since we are always on the lookout for new Japanese restaurants, we decided to come here. Tried quite a few things on the menu and most of them were a miss:
- The sashimi seemed sub-par. Certain pieces were fibrous and chewy. Albeit, the salmon was decent.
- We had several nigiri pieces and nothing really stood out.
- The wagyu over a bed of mushrooms was a disaster.
- The key redeeming dishes were the toro with daikon and soft shell crab karaage.

The service was good.

Overall, mediocre food/experience and definitely not worth the price point.
author: Ankur V.

description:
Omakase with bar seating on a super busy friday night. Staff was friendly, Chef Tony was swamped  but worked like the pro he is. 

Omakase $125 included:
Two oysters
Huge prawn with its eggs
Scallop dish
Uni dish
A5 over mushrooms
7-8 pieces Nigiri
Clam soup
Dessert


Everything tasted amaazing, but my husband said the pieces were too tiny :) wanted to add on more food but Chef Tony was too busy for us to comfortably ask him for more food.
author: Doby H.

description:
Two word summary: underwhelming and inconsistent. C+ student parading as a an A+ student. If the cost were lower, this would be a solid 3. but at this price, the cost/value/quality was 2 stars

We got the Omakase. 

Let's start with the good. 
- This is a large quantity of food
- Sake was good
- Some of the bites were delicious--especially some surprise hits, including the papaya dish
- Most of the fish was fresh and high quality; even their uni was delicious 
- Chef offered a free revisit of one of the nigiri course (while some omakase restaurants charge an additional a la carte fee)


Now the bad.
- The pacing was a mess. It took 18 minutes before we even started. We were sitting at the bar confused and unsure 
- The chef who was in front of us was clearly new, and while I'm down for training, it seemed like he was SO green, he didn't know any of the basics. That's disheartening for a $125 meal
- There was a fly in the fish refridgerator. We notified the chefs, and they just sort of gave up
- In the first course, we had uni on top of crab. The uni was delicious however all three of us in our group had crab shell in the crab. We notified the chefs, and they didn't do anything
- when the first course was dropped, no one said anything to us. they didn't explain what we were eating, just dropped it. We had to ask for help
- as we got into the nigiri course, they started with toro -- two rounds of toro-- starting with that heavy and fatty of a fish seems questionable 
- The nigiri pieces were dropped on the same piece of wood, and the wiping of the wood only occurred once every three nigiri, so flavors were blending and not in a good way
- they were heavy-handed on the wasabi, and even after we told them that the wasabi was too strong, and they asked for feedback, they didn't change anything
- the fish cuts were extremely inconsistent from person to person; within our group it seemed like each of us was getting a different cuts of the same fish. When we brought this up, we were essentially told we don't understand how fish works
- some of the fish was cut so poorly that it ended up being so chewy that we couldn't even gnaw through. we left those chunks on the plate, and no one said anything
- On one dish, the sticker of the fruit was still left on the fruit, again we brought this up, and nothing happened (not even a courtesy discount or drink or fish or even acknowledgment )
- The hot dishes came at wildly different temps between our group. One person had chawanmushi that was so hot, she could barely eat it. The other two in our group had cold dishes
- They used truffle in EVERYTHING. It was like a trick they couldn't stop performing. It overpowered the fish, and didn't add to the experience. One of the nigiri servings was literally just a ball of rice sprinkled with flecks of shaved truffle. No one needs that. 
- the layout of the sushi bar is problematic. The sushi chef kept asking us to move our plates so he could put the fish on them, and occasionally he gave up and just threw pieces of nigiri on to the plate from afar
- the three chefs were not in sync. Sometimes each chef would tell us exactly the same thing. But, they didn't seem to be working together. It was odd to be so close to that dynamic.

Overall this experience was somewhat bizarre. It felt like an impression of a fine sushi experience, but not the real thing. I think it would have been even worse at a table, so I'm glad that we at least were sitting at the bar.
author: Amy C.

description:
I sat at the sushi bar so I got a good view of everything Chef Tony was serving us. Tony was NYC Masa's apprentice and I've been wanting to go to Masa so when I heard one of his chefs had come to SF I wanted to try it. 

Kingza has a edomae style with Tony's own twist. I highly recommend it!!!
author: Josh C.

description:
Price: High but Worth it
Decor: Small and somewhat cramped 
Food: Unless you are a sushi pro I would recommend omakase but keep an open mind.
Drinks: dassai 50 (Affordable/Best flavor) 
Most dishes were craveable - Unforgettable flavors will definitely comeback

We went to dinner early which turned out to be the best choice once more people started to roll in it became quite loud.
author: Cameron M.

description:
Brand new restaurant in the former Kiji sushi space . . . It's obvious the sushi chef is professionally trained. The sushi was super fresh, perfect temperature and cut you normally find in high end sushi spots. With that said, the chef's stifled potential was the pink elephant in the room.  

The staff was eager and enthusiastic, however, got the general vibe the restaurant is still in its beta testing phase, and lacks the confidence to decide between becoming a general sushi spot or more high-end chef's choice style (omakase). 

One can only imagine behind the scenes drama . . . 

Is current management going to stifle his creativity? 

Will he be seen wandering Safeway at midnight buying Philadelphia cream cheese for the city's named rolls while wondering what happened to his potential? 
Or
Will he create a cult following?
It's not a soap opera.
It's a sushi-opera.
Looking forward to see what happens on . . . As the Wasabi Turns
author: Heather A.

description: Good and helpful service; they helped us navigate some of the more unusual choices. Sushi was like butter! Yummmm!
author: Mrs. S.

description:
Just ok...I don't get the hype and this place is most definitely not even close to the best sushi, as some reviews have put it. The few good things they did serve were fairly good -- like the Santa Barbara uni, and the sweet raw shrimp w the fried head -- but I've definitely had better elsewhere. Most things were 'not memorable' to 'just ok' -- like the wagyu and most pieces of sashimi and sushi. There were 1 or 2 things that was downright terrible -- like the vinegary caviar with some kind of fish in the middle thing (not kidding we couldn't figure out what kind of fish it was because it was swimming in overpowering vinegar). Let's put it this way, even the mass-produced omakase at Sugarfish by Nozawa beat them on both quality and price...and that's literally mass-produced omakase for the beginner!

In the grand scheme of top notch sushi places that serve omakase, it wasn't overly expensive. I actually wish they would charge more, AND up the quality AND make the cuts of fish respectable...then I wouldn't feel like I got duped into going to a place hyped up by yelp reviewers whose idea of good sushi is a spicy tuna roll.
author: j k.

description: Incredibly fresh fish + skilled sushi chefs. Try the truffle chawanmushi, the kanpachi, and the uni. Love this place and it is one of those atypical spots in the mission where it is both delicious and easy to find a table
author: Sid D.

description: The sushi was very good and I received very good service. I went to Kingza by myself, which in some restaurants means means a small table in some corner, but I was given a prime table by the window, and I wasn't treated any differently than a larger group.  The waiter allowed me to switch in the middle of my service from individual sushi orders to the combo, which was a much better deal.  I really appreciated the good service I received as an individual diner.  The sushi was very tasty, although a little higher priced and a little smaller than in other places.
author: Kim K.

description: Amazing fish, but a completely dysfunctional kitchen resulting in one of our orders arriving after 20 minutes, our shared appetizer 10 minutes after that, and the second main order finally showed up after more than an hour. The explanation was "the head chef is out tonight," which really doesn't cut it. Avoid this restaurant for a few months until it closes or hires competent management.
author: Jacob W.

description: Best Sushi in all of San Francisco hands down (Tony your amazing)! The only real complaint I have is that I had two servers which isn't the best experience when you want peace, but my "main" server wasn't the best. She wasn't the brightest and had to ask her chef the name of the fishes which ruined my appetite and didn't check on us enough. I wish the young man who served my water would of served me instead since he engaged in conversations as for treating us as fast food customers like our main host did (terrible).
author: Arianne B.

description: I have eaten at this great little neiborhood restaurant 3 times now. I wanted to make sure it was as good as I thought it was. Again the food was spectacular and the service was awesome. This is without a doubt the best Japanese omakase in town.
author: Michael F.

description: I can't tell you how good the food is in this place. Friendly service, warm environment. Great to watch Tony do his thing! Were you looking for a neighborhood restaurant in a city like San Francisco with amazing food? Well, you got it! Thank you guys..
author: Serhat T.

description: Great and impressive.   Get to eat different type of fish as Omasake.   I will come again next time
author: Hanns C.

description: OMG Omakase!  Chef and staff are all super fantastic and the food will blow your mind!
author: Slinky ..

description: I just came by this little Japanese restaurant, it was a big surprise for me that there is this hidden gem in San Francisco. This is a real authentic omakase restaurant,the fish is fresh the knife work is superb. And love the lychee ice cream. Recommend for people that loves authentic Japanese cuisines.
author: Yong Tang Z.

description:
Newly opened so, for now, under the radar.  We did the omakase which is definitely the way to go. The chef wholesales truffles and the first set of appetizers showcases the ingredient.  For those wondering, truffles + Japanese food= wonderful.   

Omakase sushi was very good, though I would say not quite as amazing as others I've had in NYC.   But, the appetizer set prior was among the best we've had-- truffled chawanmushi, wagyu with truffle, uni custard on papaya, etc.   Still, make no mistake, the sushi is far better than your general Japanese restaurant and is comfortably among the top tier of sushi in SF.  

At $125 per omakase, I'd put this as a great deal given the amount of food that was served.  

In short, fantastic find, hope I can still get a seat in a year.
author: Chen Y.

description: I came here a few months ago, and I promised chef Tony that I'd give a review after the great night of Sushi. He apparently came from Masa in the past, and is a fellow New Yorker!
